courseTitle: Determination of Water Hardness by Titration

pageData.titleName2: Determination of Water Hardness by Titration

pageData.text: Complexometric titration is a common analytical technique based on the ability of certain organic compounds to form stable complexes with metal ions in solution. If the complex formed has a known organic compound to metal ion ratio, it can be used to determine the metal ion concentration. In this investigation, a known concentration of <button class='glossary-text'>EDTA</button> is complexed to calcium ions to determine water sample hardness. Next, the EDTA titration is used to test the effectiveness of an ion exchanger that removes calcium ions from solutions.

pageData.text: The term “hard” in reference to water commonly refers to a higher concentration of magnesium and calcium ions. Water picks up these extra minerals when it travels over limestone, which releases calcium, and dolomite, which releases magnesium, prior to entering the water supply. When water is described as “soft” these minerals have been removed by adding salt to the water, oftentimes resulting in elevated levels of sodium. Some researchers feel this could raise concerns for people who struggle with high blood pressure<sub className=bodySupscript>1</sub>.

When <button class='glossary-text'>hard water</button> evaporates, it leaves behind a residue (usually calcium carbonate), also known as hard water stains. This mineral residue can build up within water pipes and decrease a home's water pressure. To find an example of hard water stains in your home, try looking at your showerhead.

pageData.text: Water is essential for sustaining life. The cells that make up all organisms maintain an inner aqueous environment. This aqueous environment is necessary for the chemical reactions and material transport (e.g., food, gases, and waste) needed to maintain life. On the whole organisms scale, humans use water for drinking, cleaning, sanitation, recreation, and manufacturing.

Chemically pure water containing only H<sub className=bodySubscript>2</sub>O<sub className=bodySubscript></sub> molecules is a relatively rare occurrence. The nature of its chemical structure allows water to dissolve or dissociate other compounds. Water is a <button class='glossary-text'>polar molecule</button>, meaning it has partial charges. In water there are partial positive charges on the hydrogens and the oxygen has a partial negative charge (see Figure 1 below). A positively charged species (atom or ion) will be attracted to the negatively charged oxygen,whereas a negatively charged species will be attracted to the positively charged hydrogens. As water molecules separate the compound molecules, the compound will dissolve or dissociate (Figure 1).

pageData.text: Rocks are a mixture or aggregate of minerals and mineraloids. When water comes into contact with rocks, some of the water-soluble minerals will dissolve in the water. Some of these water-soluble minerals contain monovalent cations (Na+ or K+) or multivalent cations (Ca2+ or (Mg2+). Water “hardness” is a measure of the dissolved multivalent cations in water. When water has a high multivalent cation concentration it is considered to be “hard.” Conversely, water with a low multivalent cation concentration is said to be “soft.” We should be aware of water hardness because the additional mineral content is preferable for some applications including improving the taste of drinking water, but is detrimental to others such as the effectiveness of soap. Water hardness varies with geographical location, largely due to how the fresh water is obtained. In areas where tap or potable water is obtained from surface water sources, such as lakes and rivers, the water is relatively soft. When water is obtained from ground water sources, such as wells, the water may be hard due to the bedrock composition and the minerals it contains. Dissolved minerals can contain many ionic species including calciumions (Ca2+), magnesium ions (Mg2+), bicarbonate ions (HCO3-), and sulfate ions (SO42-). The quantities of ionic species in determine whether it is temporarily or permanently hard.

pageData.text: Temporary hardness is caused by dissolved calcium or magnesium  bicarbonate. Rain water, which is naturally acidic, dissolves rocks like limestone that contain carbonates (e.g.,CaCO<sub className=bodySubscript>3</sub>). Bicarbonate ions are formed through ionic dissociation of CaCO<sub className=bodySubscript>3</sub> and subsequent carbonate protonation, shown in Equation 1.

A calcium carbonate molecule is at equilibrium with a calcium ion with positive 2 charge plus a carbonate ion with negative 2 charge, which in the presence of hydrogen ions, is at equilibrium with a bicarbonate ion with a negative 1 charge plus a calcium ion with a positive 2 charge.

A calcium carbonate molecule is at equilibrium with a calcium ion with positive 2 charge plus a carbonate ion with negative 2 charge, which in the presence of hydrogen ions, is at equilibrium with a bicarbonate ion with a negative 1 charge plus a calcium ion with a positive 2 charge.

pageData.disc: Equation 2. 2 negatively charged bicarbonate ions in an aqueous solution are at equilibrium with a gaseous carbon dioxide molecule plus an aqueous carbonate ion with a negative 2 charge plus a molecule of liquid water.

pageData.text: Calcium or magnesium bicarbonate-derived hardness is considered temporary because bicarbonate can be removed by heating the water sample. Boiling causes HCO<sub className=bodySubscript>3</sub><sup className=bodySupscript>-</sup> to form CO<sub className=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) and CO<sub className=bodySubscript>3</sub><sup className=bodySupscript>2</sup><sup className=bodySupscript>-</sup> (Equation 2). As the gaseous carbon dioxide leaves the system, the calciumions <button class='glossary-text'>precipitate</button> as calcium carbonate (CaCO<sub className=bodySubscript>3</sub>). Solid precipitates formed by <button class='glossary-text'>hard water</button> are collectively called limescale or just scale. Scale production and accumulation is potentially detrimental to any application where water must be heated. Scale can also build up in showers, bathtubs, and sinks.

Permanent hardness is caused by calcium and magnesium salts that are not removed by heating, such as sulfates. Calcium and magnesium sulfates can only be removed using an ion exchanger. Household ion exchangers are called water softeners. Water softeners exchange the calcium and magnesium ions for sodium ions and make the water “softer.” Ca2+ and Mg2+ ions are a concern for any application involving a (soap or detergent). Hard water prevents surfactants from forming the lather of bubbles needed for cleaning purposes because the surfactant, usually the sodium salt of a , forms a with the calcium ions in solution. The result is a white precipitate (soap scum) instead of bubbles or lather. Manufacturers often add metal-complexing agents like to soaps to improve latherability regardless of water hardness.

Many metallic ions are capable of forming complexes. This occurs when coordinating covalent bonds form between the metal ion (electron pair receiver, referred to as a and a ligand (electron donor, also known as a ). A ligand that interacts with the metal through a single electron pair is referred to as a (dentat is Latin for “toothed”). Examples of monodentate ligands are chloride, nitrate, or sulfate ions. Coordination through two electron pairs is a , and coordination through more than two pairs is a . Carbonates or glycols can be bidentate ligands. They can either bind to more than one metal or bind to a single metal atom twice. A polydentate ligand is also called a (chela is Greek for “claw”). A common polydentate ligand is heme which binds Fe2+ ions and is a major component of hemoglobin, a blood protein that transports oxygen and is responsible for blood's red color.

pageData.text: Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (<button class='glossary-text'>EDTA</button>) is a common <button class='glossary-text'>polydentate ligand</button>. It forms complexes with almost any metallic ion. It is considered one of the most important <button class='glossary-text'>chelating agent</button> in analytical chemistry, but it also has industrial applications; can be found in cleaners, cosmetics, and food; and is used for chelation treatments in humans to remove toxic heavy metals from the body. EDTA is referred to as a hexadentate ligand because one EDTA molecule coordinates a single metal ion through six atoms, four carboxylic acid oxygens, and both nitrogen atoms. It forms an octahedral geometry around the metal ion. The most commonly used EDTA is a disodium salt that forms a one-to-one complex with divalent metal ions such as Ca<sub className=bodySupscript>2</sub><sub className=bodySupscript>+</sub> or Mg<sub className=bodySupscript>2</sub><sub className=bodySupscript>+</sub>. When dissolved in a slightly basic solution, the primary species is the tetra-anion, EDTA<sub className=bodySupscript>4</sub><sub className=bodySupscript>-</sub> (Figure 3).

EDTA's effectiveness as a complexing agent is affected by pH because the carboxylic acid group electron pairs are only available to the metal in a slightly basic environment. EDTA is most effective at high pH; however, at high pH many metal ions complex with hydroxide ions. If the pH is too high, free hydroxide ions compete with the chelating agent for the metal cation. For each type of metal ion and chelating agent, there is an optimum pH for the titration.

pageData.text: Complexometric titrations use an indicator that changes color in the presence or absence of metal ions to accurately determine the metal ion concentration in solution. A good complexometric indicator is also a complexing agent that changes colors when it loses its metal ion. A variety of substances have a pair of unshared electrons that can serve as a complexing agent (e.g., ammonia, thiocyanate, and even water), but these are usually colorless. A good complexometric indicator also forms a weaker complex with the metal ion than .

During a complexometric titration, EDTA is added to a solution of metal cations and a strong metal-EDTA complex is formed. Once all the free metal ions have been bound, the  EDTA will compete for the metal ions complexed with the indicator. Since EDTA is a stronger metal complexing agent, it will ‘steal’ the metal ions from the indicator. As the indicator loses its metal ions, it will change color, creating a colorful and sharp complexometric end point.

In this titration Calmagite, 3-hydroxy-4- (2-hydroxy-5-methylphenylazo) naphthalene-1-sulfonic acid, is used an indicator for both calcium and magnesium. The equation below shows the competition reaction between the calmagite indicator (In) and EDTA for Mg and the colors associated with each state.

pageData.text: Calmagite works best if both magnesium and calcium are present in the sample. With calcium alone, the Ca-calmagite complex breaks apart at higher pHs making it difficult to determine an accurate end point. Consequently, calcium cannot be directly titrated with EDTA using calmagite as the indicator. However, the Mg-calmagite complex is not pH sensitive and if a small amount of Mg<sub className=bodySupscript>2</sub><sub className=bodySupscript>+</sub> is present in the sample, a good, sharp end point can be achieved. Therefore, adding a small amount of magnesium chloride to the EDTA titrant is standard practice. <button class='glossary-text'>Hard water</button> samples contain magnesium, meaning that the addition of magnesium chloride is unnecessary. In this investigation, Mg<sub className=bodySupscript>2</sub><sub className=bodySupscript>+</sub> is present and sharp end points are possible.

Before the titration begins, a small amount of the magnesium is complexed to the calmagite and the rest of the calcium and magnesium ions are free in solution. As the EDTA titrant is added, the calcium complexes with the EDTA and produces protons (see Equation 3). The presence of a pH 10 buffer will keep the solution within the proper pH range.

pageData.disc: Equation 3. A calcium ion with positive 2 charge plus an EDTA ion with negative 2 charge is at equilibrium with a calcium-EDTA complex with negative 2 charge plus 2 positively charged hydrogen ions.
pageData.altText: Equation 3. A calcium ion with positive 2 charge plus an EDTA ion with negative 2 charge is at equilibrium with a calcium-EDTA complex with negative 2 charge plus 2 positively charged hydrogen ions.

pageData.text: The calmagite complexes to any free Mg<sub className=bodySupscript>2</sub><sub className=bodySupscript>+</sub>or Ca<sub className=bodySupscript>2</sub><sub className=bodySupscript>+</sub> ions in solution. However, during the titration, an equilibrium exists between the Ca-<button class='glossary-text'>EDTA</button> and Mg-EDTA complexes. The calcium-EDTA complex is favored over both the Ca-calmagite and the Mg-EDTA complexes (Equation 4). Therefore, as the titrant is added to the analyte, both the free calcium in the analyte and the calcium bound to the indicator will form Ca-EDTA complexes. Once all of the free and indicator-bound Ca<sub className=bodySupscript>2</sub><sub className=bodySupscript>+</sub> ions have been complexed with EDTA, the free Mg<sub className=bodySupscript>2</sub><sub className=bodySupscript>+</sub> ions and then those complexed with the indicator will bind to the EDTA. The red solution will begin to turn purple when some of the calmagite is metal-free. Once all of the magnesium is bound to the EDTA rather than the calmagite, the end point is reached and the indicator changes color to blue as shown in Equation 5.

pageData.text: The EDTA-calmagite complexometric titration end point is used to calculate water hardness. Water hardness is reported as ppm CaCO<sub className=bodySubscript>3</sub> (equivalent to mg CaCO<sub className=bodySubscript>3</sub> /L) because EDTA solutions are standardized using CaCO<sub className=bodySuscript>3</sub> . Water hardness is calculated stoichiometrically.

Distilled or deionized water should be used for titrations involving calmagite because calmagite forms complexes with transition metal ions that may be present in tap water, bottled water or purified water. Distillation removes ions by boiling water and allowing the steam to condense away from the ions. Deionization removes ions using an ion exchange column.

pageData.altText: Equation 6. The stoichiometry calculations for determining the parts per million of calcium carbonate in a water sample. First, calculate your moles of calcium carbonate. Your milliters of EDTA over 1, times 1 liter over 1000 milliliters, times 0.01 moles EDTA over 1 liter, times 1 mol calcium carbonate over 1 mol EDTA, equals your moles of calcium carbonate. Second, calculate your milligrams per liter of calcium carbonate. Your moles of calcium carbonate over your milliliters of water sample, times 100.1 grams calcium carbonate over 1 mole calcium carbonate, times 1000 milligrams over 1 gram, times 1000 milliliters over 1 liter, equals your milligrams per liter of calcium carbonate. This final value is equal to the parts per million of calcium carbonate.

This final value is equal to the parts per million of calcium carbonate.

pageData.text: An ion exchange column contains a porous, polymer resin. Before use, the resin contains sodium (Na<sub className=bodySupscript>+</sub>) ions, which are attracted to active sites in the polymer. When the resin comes in contact with a solution containing a large concentration of a different ion like Ca<sub className=bodySupscript>2</sub><sub className=bodySupscript>+</sub>, the calcium ions replace sodium in the active site (Figure 4).

pageData.altText: Figure 4. Diagram showing how the ion exchange resin reacts to bind with calcium ions by releasing sodium ions
pageData.desc: Figure 4. Diagram showing how the ion exchange resin reacts to bind with calcium ions by releasing sodium ions

pageData.text: Washing the column with a brine (sodium chloride) solution that has a high sodium ion concentration can reverse the process. Many water softeners use ion-exchange resin to reduce water hardness and are programmed to re-charge with dissolved sodium chloride at regular intervals.

pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for activity 1 of this investigation. Before starting any activities, label your supplies, and prepare the hard water, the end point sample, and the ion exchange column. You will start activity 1 by measuring the hard water analyte into the flask. Next, you will add calmagite indicator to the analyte, then, titrate the analyte with EDTA solution until the end point is reached. Next, measure the volume EDTA solution used. Repeat the titration for a total of three trials. Finally, calculate the water hardness for each trial.

Use a grease pencil to label three 1.25-oz plastic cups. Label the first “<button class='glossary-text'>EDTA</button> ,” the second “End point,” and the third “Soap.”

Use a grease pencil to label four 10-oz plastic cups. Label the first cup “pH 10 Buffer,” the second “<button class='glossary-text'>Hard Water</button>,” the third “<button class='glossary-text'>Soft Water</button>,” and the fourth “Tap Water.”
Hold the buffer capsule over the cup labeled “pH 10 Buffer.” Twist each end of the capsule in opposite directions to separate it and pour the powdered contents into the cup.
Measure 100 mL of pure water using the 50-mL graduated cylinder and pour it into the cup containing the buffer capsule contents.
Stir using a plastic spoon until completely dissolved.
Open the Hard Water Mix and scoop one minispoon of the powdered contents into the cup labeled “Hard Water”
Measure 100 mL of pure water using the 50-mL graduated cylinder and pour it into the cup containing the hard water mix.
Stir using a plastic spoon until completely dissolved.
Use the 10-mL graduated cylinder to measure 9 mL of pure water and then pour it into the clean 25-mL Erlenmeyer flask.
Use the 10-mL graduated cylinder to measure 1 mL of pH 10 buffer and add it to the pure water in the Erlenmeyer flask.
Add approximately 3 drops of the calmagite indicator solution to the contents of the Erlenmeyer flask.
Gently swirl the flask to mix the contents.

The solution in the flask should be blue or purple in color, showing that the pure water contains no calmagite complex-forming metal ions. If metal ions are present they will complex with calmagite and the flask solution will complex with calmagite and the flask solution will be pink.
Take a photo. Pour the flask contents into the “End point” cup. Use this cup as a color reference to determine the end point of each titration.

typeBefore.title: Preparing the Microscale Ion Exchange Column (14 steps)

typeBefore.desc: Preparing the Microscale Ion Exchange Column

pageData.text: Gather together a 10-mL syringe, cotton ball, pipet, and the ion exchange resin.
Open the package containing the syringe and remove the plunger from the graduated barrel. Set the plunger and barrel aside and discard the packaging in the trash.
Use your hands to pull or tear the cotton ball in half.
Insert one piece of the cotton ball into the syringe barrel. Set the other piece aside for later use.
Use the pipet to push the cotton ball into the barrel as far as possible. Remove the pipet from the barrel, leaving the cotton ball piece stuck inside.
Remove any cotton lint that may be stuck on the pipet and retain it for later experimental use.
Pour the contents of the ion exchange resin bottle into the weigh boat.
Hold the syringe barrel with the tip/cotton side down in one hand. Keep the barrel in this position during the next three steps. Pick up the weigh boat in the other hand.
Gently bend the boat in half and pour the ion exchange resin over the cotton layer in the barrel. Continue pouring until the ion exchange resin reaches the 10-mL mark on the syringe.
Tap the barrel tip on the table to settle the resin layer. If necessary, add additional ion exchange resin and repeat tapping until the settled resin reaches the 10-mL mark.
Insert the second cotton ball piece on top of the ion exchange resin without disturbing the resin. See Figure 5.

pageData.altText: Figure 5. Diagram of assembled ion exchange column
pageData.desc: Figure 5. Diagram of assembled ion exchange column

pageData.text: Gently insert the plunger into the barrel without disturbing the cotton or ion exchange resin.
Set the ion exchange column on its side for use during Activity 2 and 3.
Rinse and dry the weigh boat then return it to the equipment kit.

In Activity 1, you will determine the hardness of hard water samples by performing three trials of a titration using <button class='glossary-text'>EDTA</button>  solution as the titrant and calmagite solution as the indicator. You will repeat this same procedure to determine the hardness of tap water samples.

Use the 10-mL graduated cylinder to measure exactly 5.0 mL of “Hard Water.” A pipet can be used to add or remove small volumes of “<button class='glossary-text'>Hard Water</button>” to make it exactly 5.0 mL.
Pour the 5.0 mL of “Hard Water” into the clean 25-mL Erlenmeyer flask.
Use a 10-mL graduated cylinder to measure 1 mL of the pH 10 buffer and add it to the “Hard Water” in the Erlenmeyer flask.
Add approximately 3 drops of the calmagite indicator solution to the “Hard Water” in the Erlenmeyer flask.
Take a photo. Place the Erlenmeyer flask on the white sheet of paper. The white background will make color changes more noticeable
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: To fill the syringe, first push the plunger completely into the barrel. Submerge the tip of the syringe in the solution and slowly pull the plunger out. Fill past the 1-mL mark. If air bubbles are present, invert the syringe, tap sides of the syringe to dislodge the air bubbles, then push the plunger until all the air bubbles are expelled. This may require several cycles of expelling/drawing up the <button class='glossary-text'>EDTA</button>  solution to ensure the syringe is free of all air bubbles. It is important that no air bubbles are in the syringe in order to get accurate readings.
Look at the markings on the 1-mL syringe and become familiar with reading them.
Pour approximately 10 mL of EDTA solution into the appropriately labeled cup. This solution will be used to fill the syringe.
Fill the 1-mL syringe with EDTA solution.
Record the initial volume of EDTA in the syringe to the nearest 0.01 mL in the Data Table for Hard Water Trial 1.
Add EDTA from the syringe dropwise, swirling the flask between each drop, until the color of the flask solution turns purple. The purple color indicates that the end point is near.

If all the EDTA solution from the syringe has been expelled and the flask solution is still pink, repeat Steps 8 and 9 and continue the titration. Record a “0” in the “Final EDTA Syringe Reading” row and the new initial volume of EDTA in the “Initial EDTA Syringe Reading” row. Multiple values can be recorded in a single box. To calculate the “Volume of EDTA consumed,” subtract the “final” readings from their respective “initial” readings and take the sum of all the numbers.

Take a photo. Continue adding EDTA dropwise from the syringe, swirling the flask between each drop, until the color of the flask solution turns blue. When the solution remains blue for several seconds with constant swirling and is the same color as the “end point” sample, the end point has been reached.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Once the end point is reached, record the reading on the syringe in the Data Table for Hard Water Trial 1.
Dispose contents of the flask down the sink.
Rinse the 25-mL flask several times with pure water.
It is important to thoroughly rinse all glassware and syringes between each titration procedure.
Repeat Steps 1–14 twice using “Hard Water” and record the data in Data Table 1 as Hard Water Trial 2 and 3.
Perform three titrations of “Tap Water” using the same titration procedure (Steps 1–14) with tap water instead of the prepared “Hard Water.” Record the data in Data Table 2.
For each trial calculate the water hardness and record in Data Table 2. (See in the Background section for the equation).

In Activity 2, you will use an ion exchange column to soften a sample of hard water. You will then determine the hardness of the <button class='glossary-text'>soft water</button> sample using the same titration protocol as Activity 1.
Remove the plunger from the ion exchange column.
Place the metal washer onto the top of the Erlenmeyer flask.
Insert the tip of the ion exchange column into the washer hole. The ion exchange column will rest on the metal washer above the opening in the Erlenmeyer flask (Figure 6).

Use a 50-mL graduated cylinder to slowly pour approximately 35 mL of “<button class='glossary-text'>Hard Water</button>” in the column, allowing gravity to elute the solution into the flask. Take care to not overfill the column.

typeBefore.altText: Figure 6. Image left to right: Ion exchange column with metal washer and flask. Column with metal washer and flask aligned. Ion exchange column and washer sitting in flask Photo of ion exchange column and washer sitting in flask.
typeBefore.desc: Figure 6. Image left to right: Ion exchange column with metal washer and flask. Column with metal washer and flask aligned. Ion exchange column and washer sitting in flask Photo of ion exchange column and washer sitting in flask.

pageData.text: Collect approximately 25 mL of “<button class='glossary-text'>Soft Water</button>” eluent from the column.
Remove the ion exchange column and set it upright in the beaker. Remove the metal washer and set it aside.
Transfer the “Soft Water” eluent from the Erlenmeyer flask to the cup labeled “Soft Water.”
Rinse the 25-mL flask several times using pure water.
Analyze the “Soft Water” sample in triplicate using Steps 1-14 from Activity 1.
For each trial, calculate the water hardness. (See <button class='resource-text'>Equation 6</button> in the Resources tab for the calculation).
Record data in Data Table 3.

Equation 6. The stoichiometry calculations for determining the parts per million of calcium carbonate in a water sample. First, calculate your moles of calcium carbonate. Your milliters of EDTA over 1, times 1 liter over 1000 milliliters, times 0.01 moles EDTA over 1 liter, times 1 mol calcium carbonate over 1 mol EDTA, equals your moles of calcium carbonate. Second, calculate your milligrams per liter of calcium carbonate. Your moles of calcium carbonate over your milliliters of water sample, times 100.1 grams calcium carbonate over 1 mole calcium carbonate, times 1000 milligrams over 1 gram, times 1000 milliliters over 1 liter, equals your milligrams per liter of calcium carbonate. This final value is equal to the parts per million of calcium carbonate.

data.title: Bidentate ligand
data.content: Ligand that interacts with the metal through two electron pairs

data.title: EDTA
data.content: Ethylene-diamine-tetra-acetic acid, used in many commercially available products, bonds with many metal ions (chelator)

data.title: Fatty acid
data.content: Fats, oils, and waxes, carbon chains containing a methyl group at one end and a carboxyl group at the other, can be saturated or unsaturated

data.title: Hard water
data.content: A measure of the dissolved multivalent cations in water, when water has a high multivalent cation concentration it is considered to be  “hard”

data.title: Monodentate ligand
data.content: Ligand that interacts with the metal through a single electron pair

data.title: Polar molecule
data.content: A molecule in which the   distribution of electrons is uneven, one end is positive and the other end is negative

data.title: Polydentate ligand
data.content: Ligand that interacts with the metal through more than two electron pairs

data.title: Precipitate
data.content: Dissolved substance become an insoluble solid from
